bug.short_desc: Downloads manager shows wrong source when handling 30x redirect on drop

assigned_to.name: Nobody; OK to take it and work on it

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 8933875 PoCDL.html
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/62.0.3202.94 Safari/537.36
Steps to reproduce:
Host the attached PoC as well as a simple redirector then follow steps within PoC.
redir.php: <? header("Location: https://www.facebook.com/me"); ?>
Actual results:
When we drag and drop an anchor tag pointing to a file that 30x redirects towards facebook.com the download manager will show the wrong origin. It shows that the source of the download is from localhost even though the entire contents of the file downloaded is from facebook.com.
Coupling this with the fact that anything drag and dropped from the downloads manager into web page allows us to read full content victim facebook page.
Expected results:
If the download manager attempts to download a file that contains a header pointing to a new (cross origin) location then this new location should be the source displayed to prevent confusion. Which is what chromes download manager does.

What's the difference between this and having the link point to facebook directly (possibly with extra download attribute)? Like, what would fixing the redirect bit here "solve" about the security issue?
Seems to me that if you can convince the user to drag an arbitrary link to the downloads panel and then back to a web page, there's not much the browser can do to protect the user without breaking legitimate workflows (given that both drag/drop to download and drag/drop to upload are legitimate).
Of course, there's still a bug here in terms of the 'source' domain displayed, but I don't think that is a security issue - it would only be one if we gave download origin hosts the same status as the location bar and its security status, which doesn't seem reasonable. There are much simpler ways of spoofing that type of data which would fool most users, like by using a filename (which is displayed much more prominently) that matches a domain.
Again, I think this is sec-low at best and should be opened up.

(In reply to :Gijs from comment #1) > What's the difference between this and having the link point to facebook > directly (possibly with extra download attribute)? Like, what would fixing > the redirect bit here "solve" about the security issue? My argument is that the user is less likely to download a link that clearly shows it pointing to facebook. Also, download attribute doesn't work on cross origin.
> > Seems to me that if you can convince the user to drag an arbitrary link to > the downloads panel and then back to a web page, there's not much the > browser can do to protect the user without breaking legitimate workflows > (given that both drag/drop to download and drag/drop to upload are > legitimate).
Drag and dropping back and forth is fine as far as the downloads manager goes. My argument is that if the source shows 'localhost' instead of 'facebook' users are more likely to drag and drop from the downloads manager into web page because there is no indication it could potentially be from facebook.
> > Of course, there's still a bug here in terms of the 'source' domain > displayed, but I don't think that is a security issue - it would only be one > if we gave download origin hosts the same status as the location bar and its > security status, which doesn't seem reasonable.
Download origin is very important from what I've seen. Imagine if someone had a vulnerability in mozilla.org where you can inject arbitrary website into a 'Location:' header, then you could use the bug described here to download a binary from attacker controlled website and have it show 'mozilla.org' as the origin in the downloads manager. I think this is the definition of security issue.
> There are much simpler ways of spoofing that type of data which would fool most users, like by using a > filename (which is displayed much more prominently) that matches a domain.
I assume what you mean here is one can download cross origin urls with arbitrary names? It is definitely possible to have a user drag something like 'https://www.facebook.com/safeWebsite.com' into the download manager and it would show 'safeWebsite.com' as the file. But the problem is that I would say that it doesn't look as convincing as my approach. For example, most if not all firefox users are familiar with the downloads manager, so them downloading a file named 'trustme.com' wont fool as many people as my approach would because they know what a filename in a downloads folder looks like.
From my PoC's perspective, you do not see anything that has to do with facebook, from the perspective of the victim all that has happened is you downloaded an 'image' from a random website and are now asked to upload this random image. But this random image downloaded contains data from your facebook.com (as logged in) yet displays a different origin.

FWIW this is how normal anchor tags behave if we attempt to do the same. This wont download and goes straight to facebook
No download, goes straight to data uri.
No download, straight to facebook.
This will download with our chosen name showing 'data:' as origin.
--- redir.php:
I think we can track it via https://apksclub.com/

Clear your browser cache and cookies to ensure that you are fetching the latest information https://eduk8u.com/ from the server. Sometimes, outdated cache or cookies can cause the downloads manager to display incorrect source information.
